title.narrative: Emergency Health and Nutrition assistance for women, girls and boys affected by Hawiga crisis (Salah Aldin and Kirkuk)

description.narrative:
In line with the overall Cluster strategy, UNICEF will support the phased interventions under the provision of a minimum package of emergency health and nutrition care services and will support the effort to recover existing health and nutrition care system in the areas of Hawiga where the population fleeing the besieged areas are coming to seek a safe haven.
This proposal takes into account the humanitarian implications on women, boys and girls, and the most vulnerable affected by the increase in intensity of the conflict due to the planned military operations to retake the Hawiga district in Kirkuk Governorate. The proposal identifies the key humanitarian consequences of the most likely scenarios from Hawiga Operational Plan, along with specifying the preparedness and responses actions to be taken by UNICEF and its partners. As the worsening situation threatens to put more boys and girls lives at risk, the proposal has been developed to mitigate further deterioration in the humanitarian conditions through rapid, mobile and integrated response packages. The sudden influx of internally displaced persons (IDPs) from Hawiga will exacerbate the already worsening humanitarian situation in Kirkuk and Salah Aldin with limited services. Main activities will include providing all U5 affected children with basic primary health care services of immunization and nutrition (emergency vaccination with polio and measles, including all U5 in routine immunization, IYCF, growth monitoring, and distribution of micronutrients and management of malnutrition). The project will also ensure proper PHC, IYCF promotion and nutrition counselling for all mothers/ caretakers to ensure optimal growth and development of under 5 children 1. Protect all eligible girls and boys in the project sites against vaccine preventable diseases with especial attention to polio and measles through supplementary vaccination activities (campaigns) and strengthening routine vaccination services. 2. Quality nutrition services, focusing on prevention and reduction of acute and chronic malnutrition and micronutrient deficiencies in the most vulnerable children in the project sites.
